--- title: Introduction to Data subtitle: Lecture 2 title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: ../minedata-bg.png data-background-size: 600px, cover data-slide-number: none format: revealjs auto-stretch: false --- # Warm up ## Announcements - Project 1 teams have been created - HW 01 is due Wednesday, Jan 31, 11:59pm # Introduction to {style="text-align: center;"} ![](images/pandas.png){fig-align="center" width="618"} ## What is Pandas? ::: incremental - **High-Performance Library**: Pandas is a Python library for fast data manipulation. - **Core Structures**: It introduces DataFrame and Series for data handling. - **Data Processing**: Ideal for cleaning and analyzing datasets. - **Versatile I/O**: Offers extensive file format compatibility for data I/O. ::: ## Why Pandas for data mining? ::: incremental - **Streamlines Data Prep**: Optimizes data manipulation for mining readiness. - **Built-in Analysis**: Includes essential tools for quick data exploration. - **Handles Large Data**: Efficiently processes and analyzes big datasets. ::: # Pandas data structures ## Series One-dimensional array-like object containing a sequence of values with an associated array of labels, its index. ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd # Creating a Series ser = pd.Series([4, 7, -5, 3], index=['d', 'b', 'a', 'c']) # Accessing elements print("a:", ser['a']) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` a: -5 ``` ::: ::: ## DataFrame A rectangular table of data with an ordered collection of columns ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Creating a DataFrame data = { 'state': ['Ohio', 'Ohio', 'Ohio', 'Nevada', 'Nevada'], 'year': [2000, 2001, 2002, 2001, 2002], 'pop': [1.5, 1.7, 3.6, 2.4, 2.9] } frame = pd.DataFrame(data) # Selecting columns print(frame['state']) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 0 Ohio 1 Ohio 2 Ohio 3 Nevada 4 Nevada Name: state, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: ## Index objects Immutable, can't be modified by a user ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Index objects obj = pd.Series(range(3), index=['a', 'b', 'c']) index = obj.index print(index) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Index(['a', 'b', 'c'], dtype='object') ``` ::: ::: ## Case study: average rent costs ![](images/rent.jpeg){fig-align="center"} ### ðŸ’°ðŸ“ˆ {style="text-align: center;"} ::: aside Source: [Zillow Public Access Data](https://www.zillow.com/research/data/) ::: # Reading & Inspecting Data ## **First, why .CSVs?** ::: incremental - More reproducible - can see changes on GitHub - Simple file structure - Standardized - Non-proprietary (e.g., Excel) ::: ## Reading in .CSV files {.smaller} ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Loading data from CSV df = pd.read_csv('data/rent_avg.csv') df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Stats We can also extract specific summary stats ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} min_value = df['11/30/23'].min() max_value = df['11/30/23'].max() mean_value = df['11/30/23'].mean() med_value = df['11/30/23'].median() std_value = df['11/30/23'].std() count_value = df['11/30/23'].count() ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` min: 752.6666667 max: 15918.88889 mean: 1851.6283666211866 median: 1675.1491305 st. dev: 935.9883320322535 N: 472 ``` ::: ::: ## Unique values ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} pd.unique(df['StateName']) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ``` array([nan, 'NY', 'CA', 'IL', 'TX', 'VA', 'PA', 'FL', 'GA', 'MA', 'AZ', 'MI', 'WA', 'MN', 'CO', 'MD', 'MO', 'NC', 'OR', 'OH', 'NV', 'IN', 'TN', 'RI', 'WI', 'OK', 'KY', 'LA', 'UT', 'CT', 'AL', 'HI', 'NE', 'SC', 'NM', 'ID', 'AR', 'IA', 'KS', 'MS', 'ME', 'NH', 'DE', 'AK', 'NJ', 'SD', 'WV', 'ND', 'VT', 'MT', 'WY'], dtype=object) ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Melting {.smaller} Jumping ahead slightly... ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} df2 = df.melt(id_vars = df.columns[0:5], var_name = "date", value_name = "avg_price") df2.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ```{=html}

To ensure parsing is consistent and as-expected, please specify a format. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ```{=html}
